captions.text:
Get it into oversteer and just balance it
into one long slide - I love this car, it's
so good!

There's lots of power throughout the rev-range,
so it's very, very usable, but can it be as
quick around a track? Let's find out.

Say hello to the new BMW M235i. With it's
three-litre, straight six twin-turbocharged

engine, it's the most powerful 2 Series you
can buy but it costs just over £34,000 and

for that kind of money you could have this
future classic: the M3 CSL. Just over 10-years

after it was launched, this car is rightly
regarded as an M Car great.

But which one is going to be faster around
our test-track, and which one is going to
be the purer driver's car?
Well, let's find out.

The M235i's twin-turbo engine produces 322
brake horsepower and 450 Newton Metres of

torque. That's 78nm more than the old M3.
It weighs 1,470kg, so it's 85kg heavier than
the old CSL.

Launched in 2004, the M3 CSL was the most
extreme version of the E46 M3 generation.

With a carbon fibre roof, it weighed 100kg
less than the standard car and it also had

upgraded springs, dampers and brakes plus
extra power. It also came exclusively with
BMW's automated manual SMG gearbox.

Let's start with the M3 CSL: the reason this
is quite a good comparison to the M235i is

its astonishing engine is the first thing
you notice, but the reason this is a good

comparison to the M125i is a normal M3 around
this age will cost you between £6,000 and

£10,000. If you want an M3 CSL, a decent
one, then you're looking at around £30,000

to £35,000 so it's very, very similar money
and you're going to get an appreciating classic

car that's going to be an asset into the future.
More importantly, if you're about your driving

experience, you're going to get this astonishing
engine - just listen to it. It revs to 8,000rpm
and it's staggeringly good.

This car did have an automated manual gearbox,
which by modern standards is very very slow

as it shifts, so there's quite a clunk as
each gear goes in. It's not like a modern

dual-clutch system, but to be honest, you'd
forgive it for its engine - it's amazing and

the chassis is equally good. There's so much
balance in the chassis, you can just sense

when the car is in transition from understeer
to oversteer, the body control is excellent...

here you can just sense the car is going into
oversteer and you can just balance it into

one long, long slide. It's just a beautifully
balanced chassis and as I say, with amazing

body control. There's not a lot of feel through
the steering, but to be honest, there's enough

and where the chassis is so good, it doesn't
really matter.

So we've got a bit of heat into the tyres,
we're going to come round now and try to sort
out a lap-time. Let's see how we get on.

When these cars were new, they were famed
for probably not having quite enough performance

in the brakes and suffered from a bit of brake
fade, so I'm going to try and be a bit kinder

to the old girl on the brakes - she is 11-years
old after all, but let's see if we can get
a good lap-time.

Now through here, the balance of the chassis
is just beautiful. Hard on the power, there's

very little understeer and very little oversteer.
It's just a really lovely balance.

Just over 110mph going down to the chicane,
there's a blip on that downshift, but it's

as I say, a bit slow by modern standards.
It was just transitioning into oversteer on

the exit, but it didn't lose too much forward
momentum - it's just lovely, lovely balance.

Fourth gear, third... already a little bit
of a brake fade, the front end bite as you

go into the corners is just beautiful, there's
lots of sense about what's going on, so you

just know exactly where you are with the chassis.
Try not to get too much oversteer, carry the
speed on the exit. This engine is just lovely...

That's 8,000rpm through these high-speed esses
with amazing body control. I love this car,

it's so good! Down through the gears and coming
up to the last corner, resisting the temptation

to indulge in too big a slide, and around
into the last corner putting all that 8,000rpm
down onto the road and across the line.

The M3 CSL is an absolute joy to drive on
track and it lapped our circuit in 1m13.5s,
but how will the modern day M235i compare?

In the CSL you've got that amazing engine
that goes ballistic about 6,000rpm, where

in this car you've just got really quick revving.
It revs to 7,000rpm, but it's really quick

revving and lots of torque all the way through
the rev range.

You can have a dual clutch gearbox in the
M235i, but we've got one with a manual box

and I have to say that is pretty nice because
the throttle response is really good, so you

can get a really nice heel-and-toe blip on
the down-change. It's a nice manual box.

It's heavier than the CSL this car, but it
should come as no surprise as modern cars

are getting heavier and heavier. It's a really
lovely road car. It's very sort of delicate
and really enjoyable on the road.

In the practice laps, I have to say it's not
an ultimate track car. It does feel a little

bit heavy, it doesn't have the body control
of that hard-edged CSL, so you can feel there

in the oversteer when the car comes back there's
a little bit of snapback as the lateral movement
in the body starts to make itself known.

It's just not as playful or as taut as the
CSL, but this then again this isn't an M3,

it's not an M2 - it's an M235i, so it's got
an M badge, but it's not the ultimate.

But can it be as quick around a track? Well
let's find out.
So we're going to come and start the lap.

Again, I'm trying to keep it smooth as we
come up to the last corner there. The engine
is great, I have to say.

I've got it in its sportiest settings on the
chassis and obviously I've got the stability

control turned off, so across the line to
start the flying lap.

I've got to say, the M3 does feel more ballistic
in terms of its absolute straight-line performance.

Not that this car feels slow. As I say, there's
lots of power throughout the rev-range. It

just feels a little bit heavy if I'm honest
when it's compared to the CSL.

Hard on the brakes coming up the chicane,
now I am standing on the brakes a bit harder

than I was in the CSL, so we're gaining some
time under braking that's for sure. The traction

is really good on the exit of the hairpin...
I mean, it's just a very nicely sorted car,

but there's just a little bit too much movement
in the body to be an ultimate track car.

What it also does in these long corners, is
it just loads up the front-right, so the loaded

front-tyre really works hard in this car.
It works its tyres much, much harder than

in the CSL, so you're getting much more wear
on the front-tyres than you'd expect from

a rear-wheel drive car. Through the high-speed
direction change there it's also pretty stable,

but again some more movement and a bit of
squirm under braking.

Into the last couple of corners, just a little
bit of oversteer but trying not to lose too

much time. It feels quite compared to the
CSL - very civilised - and across the line.

It's been a fascinating day driving this pair
of very different M Cars: the M3 CSL has a

raucous, rev-happy engine and a super-sharp
race derived chassis, whereas the M235i is

very comfortable on the road and it's got
lots of torque.

Yet despite their differences, this pair recorded
the same lap-time around our circuit, so which
one would I choose?

Well, to be honest, I think I'd want both
in my dream garage. I'd want the 2 Series

to drive every day, and I'd want this thrilling
classic as a car I could enjoy on occasion

in the sure-fire knowledge than it's going
to be a better investment than your average
pension.

title: BMW M235i vs BMW M3 CSL on track

comments.text:
M235i for me. More modern and refined, more comfortable and just as fast 
around this track. Oh, and it's cheaper as well.﻿

comments.text:
Actually this car was originally built to homologate it to the ALMS series, 
but since the homologation rules became more strict, BMW scrapped the 
project altogether. 
http://www.diseno-art.com/news_content/2006/06/bmw-m3-gtr-street-version-e46/
 

It was originally thought that 10 cars were produced, but BMW Blog reported 
that BMW NA said that none were ever sold. 
http://www.bmwblog.com/2012/05/09/bmw-super-bild-of-the-day-e46-m3-gtr/  

It's basically concept car that never went into production for sale, so it 
technically doesn't count.

comments.author: Raúl García Hernández

comments.text:
I've had my 2015 M235i x-drive for almost two months now.  It has the 8 
speed automatic.  I believe the car they used in this video was a 6 speed 
manual rear wheel drive.  I've read the xdrive helps .2 on 0 to 60  and the 
auto tranny helps another .2 0 to 60.  I have not driven the M3, but all I 
can say is the M235i x-drive is awesome.  It is flawless.  It gets to 100 
MPH so fast it is scary.  Every day when I go out to the car I just smile 
and think   friggin A  this thing is awesome.  I've got the Gray color and 
it is conservative looking so it doesn't look like I have the mid-life 
crisis going on.  And yet I know at any time I can blow pretty much anybody 
off the road.  It is a nice feeling. ﻿

comments.text:
5:11 They just said that the CSL was 100kg lighter than a normal M3 and 
then he goes to bash the M235i for being heavy? Actually the M3 is 1570kg 
while the M235i is 1530kg, so the newer car is actually lighter. And don't 
date comparing the E46 to the new 4 series, cause it a completely different 
car. The new F30/F32 are closer to a 5 series in terms of size and weight. 
They really grew a lot in this last generation. The 2 series is really the 
spiritual successor to the E46. And the old 1 series coupe is the spiritual 
successor of the BMW E30 imo. ﻿
